thread.title: Seahawks camp countdown: Which undrafted free agent has the best chance to make the team?
thread.title_full: Seahawks camp countdown: Which undrafted free agent has the best chance to make the team? | The Seattle Times

author: Bob Condotta
title: Seahawks camp countdown: Which undrafted free agent has the best chance to make the team?
text:
Seahawks training camp begins July 31, and in our countdown to camp, we’ll answer a key question every day until the team is back on the field at the team’s facility in Renton.
Today’s question: Which undrafted free agent has the best chance to make the team?
One of the many enduring facets of the Seahawks’ rise under Pete Carroll and John Schneider has been the seemingly annual find of an undrafted rookie free agent who ends up making not only the roster, but a significant contribution.
From the class of 2011, the Seahawks found receiver Doug Baldwin and safety and special-teams standout Jeron Johnson.
Most Read Stories Video from bus driver’s body camera could cost 2 deputies their jobs Donnie Chin, Chinatown ID's 'frontline hero,' killed in early morning shooting Time for Mariners to face reality as trade deadline nears 2 killed in drive-by shooting on I-5 in Mount Vernon Lifestyle changes may guard aging brain against memory loss In 2012, receiver Jermaine Kearse, tight end Cooper Helfet and defensive back DeShawn Shead made waves.
In 2013, Alvin Bailey went from undrafted free agent in the summer to officially starting the Super Bowl the following February.
And last year, linebacker Brock Coyle and offensive lineman Garry Gilliam made the roster, the latter catching one of the more improbable touchdowns in team history to help spur the comeback in the NFC Championship Game.
The question this year may not be whether an undrafted rookie free agent makes the team, but which one?
Here are five players who might have the best shot:
OL Jesse Davis: Davis, who played collegiately at Idaho, spent much of the spring working with the second unit at tackle, where the backup spots appear wide open. The Asotin native was primarily a defensive tackle in college before switching to offense midway through his junior season and was consistently cited by Seahawks OL coach Tom Cable as a standout during OTAs and minicamp.
RB Thomas Rawls: The 5-9, 215-pound Rawls was another who impressed the Seahawks with his play during OTAs and minicamp. Rawls began his career at Michigan before ending it at Central Michigan, and could prove an intriguing option depending on how things shake out at the backup tailback spot. As his size suggests, he is considered a power runner and also has shown decent hands.
SS Keenan Lambert: Lambert has an intriguing background — he is the half-brother of Kam Chancellor. The Seahawks also have a need for some younger players to emerge at safety, particularly strong safety with Johnson having departed via free agency. Like Chancellor, he comes with a reputation for aggressive play.
S Triston Wade: Listed as a safety, the 5-11, 170-pounder from Texas-San Antonio also played some cornerback during OTAs and minicamp and in particular might have a chance as a slot cornerback.
DT T.Y. McGill: The Seahawks are always on the lookout for interior defensive line help and saw something they liked in the 6-foot, 299-pounder when he was a tryout player in the team’s rookie minicamp, signing him to the 90-man roster soon after. Another defensive lineman, end Benson Mayowa, made the roster in 2013 after initially signing after having tried out in rookie minicamp.
Two other undrafted free agents come with particularly intriguing backgrounds — long snapper Nate Boyer, a 34-year-old former Green Beret who revived his football career as a walk-on at Texas ; and receiver Kasen Williams, a former star at Skyline High School and the University of Washington whose college career was derailed by a significant foot injury as a junior .
But if Williams is healthy and back to pre-injury form, he could make some noise.
Up next: Could there really be a battle at backup quarterback?
